text: so one of the interesting research
projects we have in the lab is to look
for nuclear bases and nuclear base like
molecules which are components that are
found in RNA and DNA which is essential
to all of life in meteorites and the
idea is is that these molecules formed
on the meteorite parent body and that
were delivered to the earth via
meteorites and they have assisted in the
origins of life and potentially life
elsewhere so today I'm going to show you
a little bit about the procedure that we
use to analyze these types of materials
in the laboratory this is actually a
fragment of a meteorite in this case
this is called a yin day it's a
carbonaceous chondrite which is a
meteorite rich in our organics and a
carbon and this is these are the meter
as we typically analyze in the
laboratory we do that by just taking a
piece of the meteorite and crushing it
up in a simple mortar and pestle to get
it get the meteorite into a fine powder
the next thing we do is is that we
extract these meteorites in this case we
put a little bit of the meteorite powder
into a solution of formic acid and we
heat this up at 100 degrees Celsius for
24 hours get towards the nucleobase
fraction the meteorite we use a
technique called solid phase extraction
which is just this little column here to
clean up the the sample and after
cleaning up the sample we're left with
hopefully a clean liquid that we put
into a sample vial and this is an HP old
sample vial it will just walk over here
open the door to our hplc put the sample
in and we'll be ready to go on our
instrument this is a high-performance
liquid chromatograph which has a
photodiode array detector and that's
also coupled to a tandem mass
spectrometer this is a an ion trap
coupled to an orbit trap mass
spectrometer which gives us really high
mass resolution and high mass accuracy
which helps us identify our compounds
and so will basically do an ejection on
this instrument I can show you what we
got my name is Mike Callahan I'm a
research physical scientist in the
astrobiology analytical laboratory at
NASA Goddard Space Flight Center
